ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a significant amount of French grammar, enhanced by reading and writing abilities in the French language, and gained insights into how to become a more fluent speaker.
French language skills including oral production, reading comprehension, audio discrimination, written production, grammatical competencies, and assorted vocabulary.
I developed more French language skills in reading, writing, grammar, listening, and speaking.
I learned a lot of vocabulary and grammatical skills in French. I also improved my reading comprehension.
I learned so much about French grammar, syntax, and culture. I also gained increased proficiency with oral comprehension and speaking.
I developed many skills in French grammar as well as reading original texts in French and analyzing them further than just comprehension
More French grammer/vocab and an exposure to lots of short stories and novels.
I greatly increased my conversational and written skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The course material is interesting and the literature deals with interesting themes such as; women's role in society, immigration, single-parent experiences, the impact of war, etc. Un Sac de Billes was a wonderful book, if at times rather daunting. You also just, in general, become much better at writing, speaking, and reading French.
Weaknesses: The course feels far too dense at times. Some units feel borderline unfair in how much content you need to cover. The Course Packet feels a tad bit outdated and sometimes the assignments in the CP felt overwhelming. The unit devoted to Un Sac de Billes was incredibly interesting, but it felt extremely rushed; it was hard keeping up with everything that was happening.

Strengths - excellent geographic and cultural diversity of course materials, effective small class size for enabling seminar participation, and ample exercises and repetition for language learning

Weaknesses - every exercise in the course packet should have an answer key for providing immediate feedback
I really enjoyed this course - I thought it moved at a good pace (challenging but not overwhelming) and I appreciated the smaller class size and opportunities for questions and discussion.

The strengths are that I learned a lot, especially with workbook practice and livrables. A weakness is that the workload felt unmanageable a couple of times over the semester. The books/stories that we had to read could also be improved and selected to deal with better and less stressful topics.

The main strength is the instructor. She is absolutely the best instructor I have ever had. She legitimately puts so much consideration into every one of her classes and it shows. She goes out of her way to make class engaging, even through Zoom. She came up with a variety of different ways to engage the class, such as Jeopardy games, Breakout rooms to discuss questions, diverse course materials, the idea of having students present on topics in French culture, etc. All in all, I was able to learn so much through such a range of learning mediums. I've never had a professor, in person, or virtually, put so much effort into making the course material engaging. Secondly, she is genuinely so caring and considerate towards her students. She always mentioned that we should take care of her well-being, and she made it clear that she would always be there for us to turn to. She is a natural teacher, a natural mentor, and a naturally empathetic person.

Strengths: Extremely well organized (in Canvas), amazing professor, clear communication about expectations. Interesting texts for discussion and engaging topics. 
Weaknesses: There was less listening and speaking practice than FREN130 and there was little feedback on course packet activities.

Good mix of reading and listening exercises. I didn't find the grammar textbook very helpful as it's very dry and technical, and sometimes I had to search the internet for more comprehensible explanations. The audio programs were very helpful in integrating grammar with the reading, and I would love more of that.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course completely succeeded within its limitations as a virtual language course, particularly with the inclusion of asynchronous days
I thought that the course format (live virtual seminar) actually worked really well. I don't have any suggestions for improvement.
Discussion over zoom was as good as it was going to be.

She used a lot of course practices to make the class engaging, such as using breakout rooms a lot so that we were interacting with our peers, having us play games in teams against each other to encourage participation / engagement, and providing many review sessions and open office hours to clarify any misconceptions
The canvas was very well organized and the voicethreads were great ways to practice speaking when it wasn't always possible with COVID.
Professor Fields made great use of break out groups and online technologies to create a dynamic learning space. The use of jeapordy, kahoot, etc. was fun and engaging.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course, but I do have to caution that the workload is A LOT; FREN 130 and FREN 140 were easily my most difficult and time-consuming classes during the respective semesters when I took them. You will probably fall behind at some points, and that's honestly okay! It's a harsh and intense but also incredibly engaging and informative course that you should take if you want to really take your french to the next level.
Yes, I would recommend the Yale French curriculum to anybody interested in studying French.
I would definitely recommend this course to any students interested in French.
If you want to learn French, yes! If you dont want to commit to the workload, dont.
I definitely would. I learned so much and felt so supported by the teacher.
Absolutely. It's (as expected) a lot of work, but it definitely pays off.
If you're interested in French, definitely. It is a lot of work though, so make sure to consider that as well.

I would recommend this course to anyone wanting to study French. The workload is heavy, and sometimes it was hard being in class every day and having homework almost every day, but my French has definitely approved.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Modes of learning consisted on virtual discussion and some asynchronous courses that supplemented discussion.
Virtual live seminars
Sometimes we had asynchronous days when we got work through Canvas.
It was mainly live virtual lectures as well as optional review Zoom sessions.
Combination of virtual lectures and seminars
